comments.commentBody:
Has a great blues festival and some nice people, lived there 20 years.
The beach scene is non existant so Seal Beach is preferable in that regard. Has good restaurants and temperate weather, and golf courses everywhere. Have no complaints but prefer the east coast now.
The religious among us seem to be bored with regular people with regular lives. They like the petri dish embryo people and the dead. The rest of us apparently have lost our charm for them.
I think the idea of baptizing people is that they then can be in the Mormon heaven.
Or maybe baptizing dogs who died on the roof of cars speeding down the highway.....

Baptizing dead people who never wanted to be baptized Mormon seems like an awful waste of time and money. Couldn't the time and money spent baptizing millions of dead non-Mormons be better spent helping the living? There are plenty of volunteer activities that don't involve being repeatedly dunked for people who never wanted to be Mormon.

Proud to call Greg Regan and Josh Wetzler my friends! And proud to say I watched Jake Carr make those shots...but the reference to Rudy is a little overkill...Jake played more than just that one time, a lot more.

When I was a philosophy student, I had a dream about Kierkegaard.  He was running beside the car I was riding in, and he was angry because he was running and I was not.  So I rolled down the window and asked him if he would like to ride, and he said “No, I would prefer anger to death.”  So I said, “If you keep running like that you will die before I do.”  But this just made him angrier; so I woke up.
The psychologist who told you about your ancestors was an ignorant fool. Human evolution doesn't work that way.

As someone who has been diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder -- by a health care professional who then said, "You seem to have had this all your life" (I had panic attacks starting as a child and became agoraphobic in my mid-teens) -- I've come to see anxiety and its symptoms as my friend.

Anxiety has crippled me at time, caused me suffering, yet it is also the cause, I think, of many of the good things in my life. Those moments of dread at 3 a.m. -- okay, hours, contemplating all the horrors that may be about to engulf me -- have enabled to sketch out numerous alternatives I can try to avoid what most terrorizes me.

And on a practical level, as a former roommate once said of me, "When you lived with me, I never ran out of milk."

Medication does help. At seventeen, given a prescription much against the better judgment of my psychiatrist, who, in 1969, believed that we had to find the Freudian root cause of my anxiety, it saved my life and allowed me to pretty much go about the business of living. But I think it's not the entire answer.

One psychologist told me I was descended from the paleolithic sentries who'd guard the campfire at night, which is why I can awaken, immediately alert, at the slightest rustle and why I have, like many members of my immediate family, a startle reflex triggered by the least unexpected movement. Maybe.

I like my anxiety, and I like even more that it will always be there to surprise me faithfully, its presence ultimately a mystery.
Coventry was just about the first answer I felt sure of.

Okay, thanks guys! I wiki'd Peeping Tom, as this story wasn't anything I was familiar with.

Certainly a puzzle to remember!
well, adam, nobody came back about your DINO quibble...although he did many voices, I guess Mel Blanc will always be Woody Woodpecker for us!

Didn't like this one at first, even with the fairly easy recognition that this was a rebus, and almost stopped. It wasn't til about half-way through until I realized just how clever the theme was, and then enjoyed it.

A couple quibbles though - found the cluing for DINO too obscure, as well as PEC and COVENTRY.

Lisa Rose,

Over on the right side of this page, under SOLVING TIPS, you'll find "Solving Rebuses on Your Computer."

I have always heard SHIMMY UP and shinny up is new to
me.
i do not want sex toys or or porn stars in my puzzle

What a pleasure it was to view the Olympics Hockey - the skill, the competition, the passionate play. Viewers were on immersed in the great game of hockey.

Hockey play and players at their true potential, the game as an athletic competition

What an opportunity to develop the NHL Brand and the positive image of this great athletic skill. However the "goonishness" and fighting will eventually degrade the brand and the business.

Why allow a minority segment of the fan base to determine the image and reputation by tolerating the fighting, concussion risks, and injury incidents.

It is time for a reset to athletic skills by owners, advertising and brand sponsor companies, television, and ultimately the fans and the many businesses who purchase the entertainment tickets.

Brand authenticity, positive image, and affinity by consumers are required to ensure the growth of hockey as a sport and as a business. Why risk defection from the game by increasingly informed fans and families.

Thanks, Martin.

DEB-- Any chance the instructions can be linked somewhere more obvious? Like, say, the FAQ? I don't know that I'd ever have landed on "solving tips" to try to learn how to use the software. And Across Lite makes it easy to find the equivalent info.

Nice work. I really enjoy what the light let you do in couple of those situations. Your students/assistants get kudos for the image of the scrum of fans and the woman with the Cheshire Cat smile. Were you doing this with smaller speed lights or pretty sizeable heads?
These fabulous pics make me long for the baseball season to start!!

The photo of a large room full of students at Kim Il sung University is strange.  All the males are wearing ties.  When a "must wear tie" rule was promulgated at the Universiy of Chicago Law School some students ignored it.  Isn't a school culture with plenty of dissidents something to admire?

In the photo with the wall of officers is funny to see how much more white are the women. Anti-western and in military uniform, but they are still using lots of whitening make-up.
The biggest problem is not what the world doesn't know about N. Korea but what the North Koreans don't know about the world, including about their own country.
They are going to have a massive culture shock if the stalinist system ever opens.

David Guttenfelder's photograph of the cityscape (slide 20) is perfect: the buildings resemble prisons. North Korea is a prison; food shortages are the norm. I feel sorry for those who live there, especially the children.
Poor animals
Are these photos true?
Can't feel any magic unfortunately; the only thing I see is too much effort.., sorry

For the 'real answer' to why D'Antoni departed, look no further than Carmelo Anthony. Anthony passive aggressively gave up on D'Antoni's system; he realized he was no longer the center of attention, or the 'savior' of the team, and he stopped playing with passion.

We can already see from the comments of Woodson and the players themselves that D'Antoni's selfless style of play was not universally accepted. Woodson: "But I want everybody to know, when it comes to nut-cutting time and I've got a big shot, I'm going to Melo and Amare and guys that have done it." I mean, why phrase the comment in terms of "guys that have done it" before? Or put another way, where did that comment come from? Sure, it was Woodson who said it, but it sounds like the product of some behind-the-scenes jockeying of jealous players and/or shifty executives.

Novak, and Lin taking the big shots was clearly not appreciated by guys like Anthony who feel like they should be the ones taking those shots; and if they're not taking those shots, they won't play hard.

So what's the real answer as to why D'Antoni left New York? He couldn't win with players not willing to buy into his system - especially when one of those players is a key piece of the puzzle - and got muscled out.

The sad thing is that the Knicks are still going to lose with their current setup because Anthony is not going to be enough to lead this team to a championship. A two-win streak over the Blazers and the Pacers is not impressive.

Have you guys watched the last two games?

My 11-year-old has been chanting "Fire D'Antoni" for weeks. It was that obvious.

The team looks like a weight has been lifted - and with Chandler and Jeffries providing a defensive back line games are fun again.

Melo knows it's now or never and his focus on both ends in the last two first halves has been terrific.

Can we finally have Knick-sanity?

Hey, D'Antoni, when you get your new gig, take Lin with you.  The Knicks don't deserve him...and won't be able to utilize his talents.  He brings skill and excitement to what has become  a boring dunking contest among 7 foot giants.
The minute Dolan became owner, the Knicks were doomed.
Agree entirely.

No matter how you cut it, Dolan will never win a championship and neither will Anthony. Both are stubborn, selfish, and self-centered.

Neither has what it takes to create a great team. I just hope Dwight Howard realizes he doesn't want to stay in Orlando next year and the Knicks trade Melo and whoever else to get him.

LINsanity raised MSG stock 10%. MELOdrama brought it back down.

If LIN doesn't start, I won't watch the Knicks. I had stopped watching them years ago until LINSANITY began. Now I don't miss one game.

Let's see how long this new energy continues.
If MELOdrama starts again, trade Melo. Save your money.
